titleStmt.title: John Quincy Adams Diary Digital Project

div.p: I rose at half past three awaked by the pain of a new boil, upon my left arm near the wrist; and in my right thumb which nearly disables me for writing— Yet I did write an answer to a Letter from Alexander H. Everett— Mr Russell Freeman called upon me. He has been defeated in his election to the Legislature of Massachusetts, and has come from Sandwich to solicit some Office— He proposes to visit President Jackson, Vice-President Van Buren, and the Postmaster General Amos Kendall— He asked me if I saw any objection to it, and I answered none at-all— He complains much of the treatment he has received from the whig party—and of his want of bread— I walked to the Capitol and found upon going into the Hall of Representatives, that the three Seats which I had taken for D. Pearce, W. Sprague and N. B. Borden, had all been taken by other members in person— I took three other Seats for them, but with uncertainty whether they also will not be taken away. Met E. Whittlesey of Ohio, Stanbury the Reporter and John Y. Mason of Virginia— The two Misses Cottringer dined with us. Mrs Pawling, wife of a Coll. Pawling, a claimant for a Pension as an Officer in the Revolutionary War, left a written statement of his case, and is to call to-morrow. Mr E. A. Brown of Ohio, Commissioner of the General Land Office paid us an Evening visit— When I was Secretary of State he was a Senator from Ohio— Since which he has been Governor of the State of Ohio, and Chargé d’Affaires of the United States at the Court of Brazil—and is now Commissioner of the Land Office— Received Cards of visit from F. Granger and David B. Ogden.

My granddaughter Mary Louisa’s birth day— She is this day seven years old, and I gave her a small Polyglott English Bible— Mrs Coll. Pawling came and made a statement of her husband Coll. Pawling’s claim to the commutation or five years full pay as an officer in the Revolutionary War— She had yesterday sent me such a statement in writing which she now took back— She told me she was a Sister of Genl. Peter B. Porter— Morning visit from G. N. Briggs and P. C. Fuller members of the House of Representatives— Walk to the Capitol— Met J. Bell speaker of the last House—Sherman Page of New-York—W. B. Shepard of North Carolina members of the house, and found in the Hall nearly half the Seats taken— At Taylor the Stationer took an Album— Messrs Briggs, Fuller and Connell dined with us, Mr and Mrs Frye and their Son Thomas—Mr and Mrs W. S. Smith and Walter Hellen— When our company were all here and just after four O’Clock, Mr Van-Buren the Vice-President of the United States, with Mr Martini Chargé d’Affaires from the king of Holland, paid me a morning visit. Mr Van Buren has recently returned from an excursion to Virginia where he visited Mr Madison— He says he is in good health though confined to his house by the infirmities of old age— I answered a Letter from Edward H. Adams of Middleton-Hall near Carmarthen in South Wales— Genealogical enquiries about our Name— And a Letter from William T. Otto requesting a copy of my Oration of 4. July 1831— I sent it to him, and with it copies of the Eulogy on James Monroe, and the Oration on La-Fayette

Mr Russell Freeman visited me again this morning— He has been to see the President—the Vice President and the Postmaster General, to expose to them his distresses and his wants— The President told him there was no vacancy, and turned from him to other business— Mr Van Buren was exceedingly courteous, but since the Baltimore nomination had recommended no person to office, and Mr Kendall sent him word that if he wished to see him on public business he would receive him, but he was very much engaged— Freeman finds himself slighted, rejected mortified, and without remedy but to submit to his destiny— Mr Cushing had some political conversation with me, and particularly requested a frank communication and interchange of opinions with me; which I promised— Lyon and Norvell, are the two Senators and Reilly is the Representative-elect from the State of Michigan— Mr Norvell asked me if I had received a vote of thanks to me unanimously passed by the Convention which formed the Constitution of Michigan, for the part I took in their favour at the last Session of Congress— I had not— They said that John Biddle the President of the Convention had been expressly instructed to communicate the vote to me but was a careless man and must have neglected it, as he had to send the Constitution itself to the President of the United States— I called at the War Department, and the Secretary not being there, I returned Mr Van Buren’s visit— Met going there Beardsley, Vanderpoel, Gillet and three new Members of the New-York delegation. R. M. Johnson at his door— Connor of North-Carolina with him, and Forsyth came in just before I came away— Left a Card at Mr T. Munroe’s; again at the War Department and saw the Secretary and the Commissioner of Pensions Edwards. Mr Cass gave me a compilation of the Pension Laws—and I am to reduce my Call, to writing— Walk to the Capitol— In the Library— The Duke of Newcastle Letter to the Prussian Secretary of Legation Michel not to be found— Unwell this evening—

Both my hands are disabled. The left hand by a boil on the wrist bone, which has been inflaming several days and is now very painful, and troublesome— The right hand by a threatened whitlow under the nail of the thumb— This disability has broken in upon my early rising hour— It is in vain to be three hours waiting for daylight, without some interesting occupation— There was rain during the hours of my usual morning walk. Henry Kuhn a youth of 16. came to request a Letter from me to Mr Dickerson the Secretary of the Navy recommending him for a Midshipman’s warrant— I promised to speak to Mr Dickerson in his favour— Mr Frye called and told me that he had seen Speakman the Miller, and had concluded to retain the 100 dollars which he had reserved as satisfaction of an old claim of his which he had agreed to give up— The rain having held up I walked round the Capitol Hill after dinner, and in the Evening we finished the reading of the Dissertation L. upon the Congress of Nations I made minutes of preparation for presenting 2 Petitions at the meeting of Congress next week; but from the crippling of my hands I cannot be prepared as I had intended and flattered myself I should be— I read the Message of George M’Duffie, Governor of South-Carolina, to the Legislature of that State— It is a bold uncompromising exposition of the Southern Slave-holding policy, and opinions— Its insolence towards the free States is in even pace with its doctrines upon Slavery— I wait to see how long this tone is to be endured Semper ego auditor tantum? It would at this time be of no earthly use for me, to resist this torrent of moral depravity on one side, and of craven cowering on the other. My duty for the present is silence— Whether it may ever come to be my duty speak, is in the darkness of futurity.

I am still disabled and rose two hours later than my time— Mr Fiske sometime Editor of the Reformer Newspaper at Boston brought me a Letter of recommendation from A. H. Everett; and told me he should be a candidate for the office of Chaplain to the Senate— I called at the Department of War, and left with the Secretary a copy of the call which I propose to make in the House of Representatives for a Statement of the revolutionary War Pensioners under the act of 18. March 1818. struck off the list by the Act of May 1820 and not restored— But I said as the Session was now so near commencing, I would not trouble him to have the statement commenced, until I could ascertain whether the House would authorize the Call— Mr Cass shewed me a Letter from the central Anti-masonic State Committee of Pennsylvania, at Harrisburg, putting three or four Anti-masonic questions to him; with a note that a circular to the same effect hand been addressed to J. C. Calhoun, Judge Story, Mr M’Duffie Louis M’Lane, and some others— Mr Cass said he was a Mason; but had not attended any Meeting of a Lodge for several years— That he thought Masonry a useless, but a harmless institution That he was not a Candidate for any thing, and thought he should not answer the Letter— He said Mr Forsyth had received a similar Letter with a note mentioning other persons as having been addressed by the circular— I then called at the Treasury Department; and mentioned my intention to propose a new rule of the House, to hasten the passage of the Appropriation Bills— He said the Estimate, should be sent in, the first week of the Session; I went to the Capitol to seek in the Library of Congress for the History of the English Navigation act, but could not find it— Evening visits from Joseph Blunt of New-York, and from a young man named Langtree who last Spring, brought me a Letter of recommendation from W. L. Stone— He says he is now part Editor of the Metropolitan Newspaper at Georgetown.

This morning I finished reading Dr. William Sullivan’s Moral Class-Book, composed for the use of Schools— It has been very favourably received, and is not without merit— It is however very deficient in the loftier principles of magnanimous morality— Justice, equity, moderation and Christian piety are sufficiently recommended—but of generosity, of gratitude, of self-devotion to the good of others, of friendship of parental, filial and conjugal affections, there is little or nothing— Upon the nature and obligation of promises there is very little—it is a book of commonplace morals, suited to the ordinary intercourse of life, and solving the moral principle chiefly into selfishness— Mary Louisa in the course of her daily reading to me, finished the Book of Numbers— At the second presbyterian Church, Mr Gurley preached from Romans 5.2 “By whom also we have access by faith into this grace wherein we stand, and rejoice in hope of the glory of God” Mr Gurley uses the name of God, with annoying reiteration and always pronounces it Gaud.— At the gate of the Church I met Mr Elisha Whittlesey of Ohio, who informed me of the sudden decease last Evening of Nathan Smith one of the Senators from Connecticut, an able and valuable man— Mr Gurley gave notice there would be preaching there at 1/2 past 3 this afternoon— After Church I called to see Edward Wyer, whom I found recovering as he said from a fit of gout, but not from poverty, nor from discontent with the world— He said he had sold all he had, and was not worth ten dollars in the world— After dinner Mr Hawley at St John’s Church read prayers for the second Sunday in Advent and preached from Romans 12.11. “Not slothful in business; fervent in Spirit, serving the Lord.” I wrote a note to Dutee J. Pearce, to be delivered to him on his arrival, this Evening at Fuller’s Hotel, and read a chapter of the Dissertation M. upon the Congress of Nations

I began for morning reading Mosheim’s Ecclesiastical history. Attended at the Capitol, and met with mutual greeting many members of the last Congress— Several of the new members were introduced to me— Precisely at Noon, Walter S. Franklin, called the House to Order, and the names of the members were called over alphabetically by States; beginning with Maine—224 members answered their names— The Clerk then said that the first business of the House was to choose a Speaker— John M. Patton my next neighbour in the house moved that the election should be by ballot viva voce— This gave rise to a debate of nearly an hour; upon which the yeas and nays were two or three times demanded, and the House was perplexed for want of Rules. Abijah Mann jr. of New-York, moved that the Rules of the House in the last Congress should be adopted—upon which I stated my intention to move an additional rule to be the 58th. Mann agreed to except from his motion the 57th. rule to be considered hereafter— Reynolds of Illinois, moved also to except the 9th. and 10th. rules, relating to elections by ballot to which Mann agreed— The old rules with these exceptions were adopted— Patton’s motion at the motion of Evans of Maine was laid on the table. The ballot for Speaker was taken, and James K. Polk of Tennessee was chosen 225 votes given Polk had 132. John Bell 84 and 9 scattering. He was conducted to the Chair by R. M. Johnson and L. Jarvis— Sworn into Office by Lewis Williams, and addressed the House in a speech commendable only for its brevity— Franklin was then rechosen Clerk by Resolution, offered by Beardsley. A motion was made to proceed to the election of a Printer to the House which was adopted. Whittlesey of Ohio, moved a reconsideration, referring to the two joint Resolutions of 1819 and 1829. for the election of Printers—another hour’s debate— Beardsley finally moved, that the Printer should be under bonds, and print on the terms of the two Resolutions; which was agreed to. Blair and Rives were chosen Printers by 133 votes 59 for Gales and Seaton. 26 for Bradford and Learned; and 4 or 5. scattering— Message to the Senate Committee to P.US—adjourned near 4 O’Clock— Mary-Louisa read to me the first 2 Chapters of Deuteronomy this Evening.

Mr Mygate is a traveller to collect subscriptions for Sparks’s edition of the writings of Washington— I was a subscriber for them and had received from the 2d. to the 7th. volume inclusive; for which he requested of me a certificate subscription, with which I complied. He asked also for a recommendatory certificate which I declined to give— The House met at Noon; the hour to which they resolved to adjourn till further order.— Thompson of Ohio, from the joint Committee appointed to notify the President of the Meeting of Congress reported that he would communicate by Message at 12 O’Clock this day— His Secretary Donnelson immediately afterwards came in and delivered the Message of which printed copies were while the Clerk was reading it distributed to the members of the House— It took the Clerk upwards of an hour and a half to read the Message, many parts of which I disapprove. An order passed for printing ten thousand copies; afterwards reconsidered and 15000 copies were ordered, with the documents and 5000 copies without The annual Report of the Secretary of the Treasury on the finances was received, and 15000 copies of it were ordered to be printed. The Estimates for the year 1836. and the Accounts of receipts and expenditures for 1834 and three quarters of 1835 were also received— A message came from the Senate announcing the death of Nathan Smith a Senator from the State of Connecticut, and that his funeral would be at noon to-morrow— Isaac Toucey of Connecticut moved that the members of the house should attend the funeral, and wear crape thirty days, which was adopted and Andrew T. Judson moved the House to adjourn which also passed unanimously— Mrs Frye dined with us and Mary dined at Mr W. S. Smith’s— We had evening visits from D. J. Pearce, W. Sprague jr. and Nathaniel B. Borden, and also from Mr John Connell at which there was much conversation and some diversity of opinion upon the message

Morning visit from Messrs. Heister and Darlington, Antimasonic members of the House from Pennsylvania— They spoke of the approaching Presidential election, and Darlington said that from Letters received yesterday from Harrisburg, there would probably be a nomination of General Harrison— His second Letter in answer to Anti-masonic enquiries being deemed satisfactory— He said the Antimasonic central Committee had addressed Letters of enquiry to Mr Van Buren, and to Mr Webster— Mr Thomas C. Love, with his wife and two children a boy of 5 and a girl of 8 years of age also visited us. Mr Love represents the district of Buffalo, last represented by Millard Fillmore— He is Anti-mason, and Anti-Van-Buren— Mrs Love is a native of Hatfield, Massachusetts, and her maiden name was Maltby— Walter Hellen was also here this morning. As I entered the House, and took my Seat, the Speaker called the House to order.— The Journal of yesterday was read, and the House immediately adjourned.— The members went in procession, headed by the Speaker and Clerk into the Senate chamber, where the Episcopal funeral service was performed by Mr Higby, Minister of Trinity Church, over the remains of Nathan Smith, late a Senator from the State of Connecticut. The prayers were followed by a short funeral discourse— The procession of Carriages to the cemetery then followed— I rode with Jeremiah Bailey of Maine, Abbott Lawrence, of Boston, and George Chambers of Pennsylvania— The body was deposited at the usual receptacle, and we returned to the Capitol— I went into the Library and examined the Duke of Newcastle’s Letter to the Prussian Secretary of Legation Mitchell, in Chitty’s Law of Nations— Also Pepys’s Diary where I found some passages relating to Sir George Downing.— Evening visit from Mr Southard, Senator from New-Jersey, who Mary observed appeared to be out of Spirits—

Mr Crary the Representative-elect from the new State of Michigan came this morning, and said that the President would this day send to Congress two Messages relating to the affairs of Michigan— One concerning the boundary question— The other with the Constitution of the State and her claim of Admission to the Union— And he requested me to take charge of them in the house, and to move the reference of them to a select Committee— I said it would be perhaps more for the interest of Michigan to have the two Messages referred to two separate Committees— I would move the reference of the boundary Message, if I could get the floor in time— But as the People of Michigan were understood to be very friendly to the present Administration, it would be more useful to them to have the reference of the Constitution Message moved by a known supporter of the Administration in the House—to which he assented— At the House the first subject considered was the adoption of the Rules of the House in the last Congress—upon which I pressed the adoption of the additional rule, requiring the Committee of Ways and Means, to report the general Appropriation Bills within 30 days of their appointment, or the reasons for failing so to report them— My Resolution raised opposition, direct, and collateral, from both sides of the House—Cambreleng, Mann, Vanderpoel on one side—Mercer and Lewis Williams on the other— The rules were finally adopted; but referred to a select Committee for revisal; who were instructed to report my Rule; and to receive propositions for amendments to the rules, from any member of the House— The question, upon instructing the Committee to report my rule was carried 91 to 76.— The Messages from the President concerning Michigan were received. I moved the reference of the boundary Message to a select Committee of nine, which passed without opposition. John Y. Mason moved the reference of the Constitution Message also to a select Committee. Howard moved the Committee on the Territories, and said he should move a reconsideration of the prior reference. But the House adjourned over to Monday.

A German by the name of Peter Waine, came with a subscription book for a contribution to build a church at a place called Mountjoy, a village about a mile out of Lancaster, Pennsylvania; and three Ladies of the Sisters of Charity came, for aid to set up a cooking establishment, at the Roman Catholic orphan asylum in this City— A small contribution is the only way of satisfying this class of mendicants, nearly or quite as numerous as the religious mendicants in the Roman Catholic Countries of Europe— My neighbour Mrs Tudor also sent yesterday morning to request me to call upon her after breakfast, which I did.— She still covets the commutation of five years pay for her husband’s revolutionary services; and is yet unwilling to be a petitioner for it to Congress— She now concluded to see first the Secretary of War, and enquire if he could not gratify her wish— I returned this morning the visit of Mahlon Dickerson, the Secretary of the Navy— Then called at Mr Phillips’s lodgings at Fuller’s; but he was not at home— Then at the Patent Office to enquire for Charles Lane’s Patent, concerning which I received this morning a Letter from Solomon Lincoln— H. L. Ellsworth, the Superintendent of the Patent Office, told me that the Patent had been ordered to be issued the 25th. of Novr. That he had not Clerks enough to do the business of the Office. That Mr Lane’s Patent would be the next but one to issue; but that the Attorney General who must sign it was gone to New-York; and that when made out, it would be sent to me— I called on Govr. Lincoln— Not at home— On W. Heister whom I saw— Darlington was out. Mrs H. L. Pinckney of S.C. was there—Mrs Macomb, and Mrs Lovell were visiting her— I went to the Library at the Capitol, and examined the first and last volume of the Journals of the House of Commons—also the Lex Parlementaria, and the Debates in Parliament, for Speeches of Sir George Downing— I received this Evening, sent me by S. B. Barrell, a Letter, and parcel of printed papers from Dr George Parkman—

There was snow last Evening, sufficient to cover the ground; and it was all this day melting off, with rain this afternoon and Evening— Zalmon Wildman, a member of the House of Representatives from Connecticut, died last Evening, and a notice from Elisha Haley Chairman of the Committee of Arrangements for his funeral, was published this morning in the National Intelligencer, that it would take place from the Hall of the House of Representatives at Noon this day— I received also a circular printed note of invitation from the same Committee. I attended at the Hall, and the funeral ceremonies were performed as they usually are by order of the House— A short discourse, and an appropriate prayer were delivered by Mr Cazneau Palfrey, the Minister of the Unitarian Church in this City— The Vice-President and Secretary of the Senate, Speaker and Clerk of the House and perhaps half the members of both Houses were present— I rode in the procession to the grave-yard, with Abraham Rencher a member of the House from North-Carolina, and on returning, instead of stopping at the Capitol, came home, leaving Mr Rencher at his lodgings at Brown’s Hotel— Morning visit from George W. Lay a member of the House from New-York. I received this Morning a Pamphlet, containing four Letters from William Slade of Vermont, addressed to B. F. Hallett, Editor of the Boston Advocate, upon certain Anti-masonic Resolutions of the members of the Legislature of Vermont— A Harrisburg Telegraph, containing a correspondence between an Antimasonic Committee and Daniel Webster who comes out as sturdy an Antimason as any man in the Country. A Letter from John Howard Payne with a Knoxville Register complaining of an outrage, committed upon his person by the Georgia guard, in arresting him with John Ross the Cherokee, in the State of Tennessee, and carrying him into Georgia, and keeping him a prisoner thirteen days— And a Letter from my Son upon political affairs— Each and every one of these incidents gave me matter for meditation, and for deliberation to regulate my own conduct with reference to them— Lay was much surprised at Webster’s new zeal for anti-masonry; In the Evening I made further progress in the Dissertation M upon the Congress of Nations.

Another member of Congress Elias K. Kane a Senator from the State of Illinois, died the night before last at the house of his father who is Navy Agent here— This morning at the second Presbyterian Church I heard a young man by the name of Mason, from John 1.36. “Behold the Lamb of God”— A thoroughly calvinistic text— The emblematical representation of the deity, in the form of a beast and a bird, seems evidently to be of Egyptian origin; but how natural it would be for a heathen or a jew to imagine that Christians worshipped a sheep, and a pigeon— After dinner I attended with my Grandchild Mary-Louisa at St. John’s Church and heard Mr Hawley read the Service for the third Sunday in Advent, and preach from Hosea 10.1. “Israel is an empty vine, he bringeth forth fruit unto himself.”— The discourse was short, and not very sharply pointed— Mrs Frye and her Son Thomas were here before dinner, and also Leonard Jarvis, a member of the House of Representatives from Maine— Mr W. B. Lawrence of New-York left a Card— Mrs W. S. Smith came to tea, and her husband was here in the Evening— Jarvis has been a bitter Jackson partizan, and has the reputation of insincerity— He had a furious controversy last winter with his colleague F. O. J. Smith a partizan at least as unscrupulous as himself— After much reciprocation of ribaldry, against each other in Newspapers and Pamphlets Jarvis challenged Smith to a duel, but Smith refused to meet him— With all his party rancour, Jarvis, assumes an air of independence, and the tone of a frondeur against the Administration— This is no uncommon thing with the most inveterate party members— They affect freedom of opinion, and censure the President with little restraint or qualification— The only cue for understanding them is to watch their votes— Jarvis sometimes carries the joke so far as to fly the course, and vote against his party— The consequence of which is that they have little confidence in him— I read in the Knoxville Register the long dramatic narrative of John Howard Payne— He has suffered an abominable outrage, but I fear it is without prospect of a remedy— There is no security for the right of Life, of Liberty of property or of reputation, in any of the Slave holding States, with reference to Negroes, or Indians— I can at least give no aid to procure for him a remedy, or satisfaction.

Mr Grymes called on me this morning with a recommendatory Letter from Mr G. W. P. Custis of Arlington. Mr Grymes, is a candidate with many others for the Office of Sergeant at arms to the House of Representatives, and rests his claims on his being the Son of an Officer of the Revolutionary war, and the father of nine children, whom he finds it hard to support— I called at the Franklin Insurance Company about the renewal of two policies of Insurance which expired yesterday; but could not finish my business. At Noon, I attended at the House. The journal of last Thursday was read and the appointment of all the Committees was then announced— I am as heretofore Chairman of the Committee of Manufactures—also Chairman of the Select Committee on the Michigan boundary Message; and second member of the Committee on the Rules of which Abijah Mann jr. of New-York is Chairman— B. C. Howard now made his motion for reconsideration of the vote of last Thursday referring the Boundary Message to a Select Committee— Elisha Haley of Connecticut then announced the decease of his Colleague Wildman and that he had been buried on Saturday and moved a Resolution of 30 days mourning which passed without Opposition— Immediately after the Secretary of the Senate came in and announced the death of Elias K. Kane, Senator from the State of Illinois and that his funeral would be at half past 12 this day— The House immediately at the motion of Zadock Casey of Illinois voted to wear crape 30 days, and to attend the funeral; and adjourned— The funeral service in the Senate chamber was performed by Mr Post, who read the 14th. Chapter of Job, and made a brief exhortation and prayer, suited to the occasion— I went to the grave-yard with George N. Briggs,—and found the monument to Genl Brown, which is at the Southwest Corner of the yard— Returning to the Capitol I bespoke my Newspapers, and took the names of the Committees of which I am a member, and of the Committees of foreign relations and on the Territories— Called on Messrs. Lyon, Norvell and Crary at Fuller’s, and consulted them, with respect to the Michigan Questions— They wish that the references may be to Select Committees.

Mrs Freeman, widow of Constant Freeman, heretofore one of the Officers of the Treasury Department, came this morning, with a Petition to Congress, which she wished me to present, praying for a grant of land under certain Resolutions of the Old Congress and Acts under the present Constitution in behalf of Canadian Refugees— I was thus detained, so that I found the House in Session— The Journal had been read, and the ballot was just about commencing for a Sergeant at Arms—the former Officer Robert Randolph having lost all support from neglect of his duty at the last Congress— Patton told me that Randolph had asked him to nominate him, which he had refused, and told him he should vote against him— He said it was painful, for Randolph had distinguished himself as an Officer in the last War— Randolph acknowledged that he had deserved to be superseded, by his remissness in the performance of his duty— There were ballotings before the election was completed; and at the last Roderick Dorsey was chosen by 122 of 220 votes— Nominated by Thomas of Maryland— His strongest competitor was J. Oliver Pease, a youth who when I came into the House in 1831 was one of the running boys, and is now not more than 19 years old— It was past three O’Clock when the choice was completed and the house immediately afterwards adjourned— Mr Philemon Dickerson came to me with a Letter from a person whom he did not name to me, but who he said was the author of one of the dissertations upon the Congress of Nations—who complained that the Peace Society instead of sending the judges all the Essays transmitted to them in competition for the prize, had themselves made a selection out of thirty or forty; and the writer of the Letter did not know whether his work was one of the selected or not— I told Mr Dickerson that the judges could decide only between those transmitted to them fourteen in number— That Chancellor Kent had read them all— That I had read and sent to Mr Webster nine; and should in a few days finish and forward to him the remaining five— This evening I read part of the Essay signed and lettered M. Our Grand child Fanny has been several days quite unwell.

The winter has set in with great severity— A Heavy Gale of wind from the North all last Night ushered in a day bitterly cold; and the Potowmac river froze over— At the House the day was absorbed in receiving Petitions and Memorials from all the States and Territories— John Fairfield a new member from Maine, presented two Petitions for the abolition of Slavery in the District of Columbia— He moved that the first should be referred to the Committee on the District— John Cramer of New-York moved that it should be laid on the table—upon which Mason of Virginia called for the yeas and nays— Everett of Vermont asked if the motion to lay on the table was made by the member who presented the petition and Faifield answered yes— The yeas and nays were taken twice—first on laying on the table carried 181 to 36. and, to lay on the table the motion to print also carried 168 to 50. I voted on both questions in the negative— I presented a Petition from Tillson Burrows, a Soldier in the last War, disabled; praying for a pension, referred to the Committee on Invalid Pensions—a Petition from Joseph Ewell and others, children of Thomas Church, a pensioner under the act of 1818. struck off the list under the Act of 1820. for the pension which ought to have been paid to him; and with this Petition I offered with the consent of the house a Resolution for a Call on the Secretary of War for a return of Pensioners under the act of 1818. struck off under the act of 1820. and not since restored—the Petition was referred to the Committee on Revolutionary Pensions—the Resolution lays over, one day. The Memorial from Mrs Margaret Freeman, for Canadian Refugee lands—referred to the Committee on Private Land-claims. The old Petitions from Plymouth and Gloucester, for Custom-house and Post Office, with the Documents and Bill of the last Session were referred to the Committee on Commerce— Revd. Dr Proudfit called me out, to enquire, if Congress would grant money to the colonization Society— I referred him to those members who favour the views of this Society which I do not—Crary sent his credentials as a member elect from the State of Michigan— S. Beardsley moved that a Seat should be assigned to him on the floor, which was opposed by C. F. Mercer— Adjourned without decision— W. Sprague jr. had a Letter from H. D. Ward Harrisburg. Anti-masonic Convention sitting.

My thermometer this morning in the open air sunk the mercury into the bulb—but it was graduated only as low as 20. I think it was down as low as 10. and the cold disables me distressingly from writing.— At the House; the doorkeeper, and assistant doorkeeper were elected— Overton Carr was rechosen doorkeeper by Resolution, and John W. Hunter by ballot— Patton nominated John B. Dade against him, but he carried the election by 151 to about 55 votes— The calling for Petitions was superseded for the day. Resolutions were taken up, and mine for a call on the Secretary of War, for the list of Pensioners under the Act of 18 March 1818. afterwards struck off the list, very luckily passed without opposition— Patton manifested some disposition to question what the list was wanted for, but did not push the enquiry— A Resolution offered by R. M. Johnson, that some fifteen or twenty copies of the Sessions documents of the House should be furnished to the Secretary of War and the subordinate bureaus of his department, was not so lucky— It was attacked first by Patton as a useless expense, and secondly by Wise, as an Executive encroachment upon the privileges of the Commons; and after a debate of an hour and a half the Resolution at the motion of John Y. Mason was referred to the Committee on Military Affairs for a Report, whether it would be useful, to furnish these copies.— The House had previously gone into a Committee of the whole on the Union—when the Speaker called me to the Chair— Beardsley offered twelve Resolutions parcelling out the various subjects of the President’s Message to the several standing and one Select Committee. The question was taken upon them all in the lump; and all were unanimously adopted—reported to the House and there also without opposition referred— Adjourned between 3 and 4 O’Clock. Immediately after dinner we had visits from Mr and Mrs Lay, with a Mr and Mrs Hyslop from New-York— My grand-child Fanny, who has been several days confined to the Nursery chamber was this Evening very unwell— Dr Huntt had attended her this Morning— I read a few pages in the second Dissertation M. upon the Congress of Nations, but was obliged to desist.

Mr Crary the representative elect from the State of Michigan, and Mr Jones the Delegate from the Territory called on me this morning and had some conversation with me, on the questions before congress involving the interests of their constituents— The purpose of some of the administration members of the house now is to take the boundary and Constitutional questions from select Committees and refer them to the judiciary Committee— Crary said he thought they would not succeed— I told him that the great object for Michigan, I thought would be to have a full report containing an exhibition of the right; and if they were confident of the favour of the Administration, it would be perhaps best for them that the reference should be to the Judiciary Committee of which Beardsley is Chairman. Mr Crary said he did not know what Mr Beardsley’s views upon the subject were— At the House, the meeting of this day was held for the purpose of receiving private Bills from the Committee of Claims; but the Speaker called the States for the presentation of Petitions— N. B. Borden, presented a petition from Wrentham for the abolition of Slavery in the District of Columbia, and moved its reference to a select Committee— Hammond of South Carolina moved that the petition should be rejected— This proposition which was wholly unexpected to Polk the Speaker disconcerted him, and he blundered in the tangles of the Rules—a debate of four hours arose between the fury of the Southern Slave holders and wiley compliances of the Kinderhook school, in which the rest of the House took no part— Granger of New-York came to me and asked me if this was to be tolerated— I told him it would be tolerated— That the Presidential Election was crushing every elementary principle of Freedom, in the free States, and that I saw no prospect of useful resistance at this time— I should say nothing— I believed no one else would say anything— There was a perfect snarle of debate upon a multitude of questions succeeding each of other one only of which was taken by yeas and nays— This was the identical question to lay on the table; carried triumphantly by the South two days ago as a test question; now voted down by themselves 121. to 95. to get a vote of rejection— The House adjourned about 4. without closing the debate— Adjourned over to Monday Whittlesey pleaded hard for leave to report his bills for private claims but without success.

There were several visitors by Cards— I received a Letter from Anthony Collamore of Pembroke concerning a claim of the widow of a revolutionary Pensioner named Gundeway—which I took to the Secretary of War— He promised to have the enquiries made, requested in the Letter, and to cause the information desired to be sent me— He said that the Resolution of the House calling for a statement of the names of Revolutionary Pensioners struck off the list had been received, and that it had been commenced even before— I asked him whether the question concerning the Michigan boundary was to be managed in the House as an Administration measure— He said no— I said I had put the question, because the motion made in the House by Mr Howard, to reconsider the vote referring it to a select Committee had that aspect— Mr Howard being a warm partizan of the administration, and having been an Official agent of the Executive to mediate between the parties to this controversy since the close of the last Session of Congress— He said he believed Coll. Howard’s motion had been entirely a suggestion of his own mind; and that it was the desire, that the subject should be left to the Committee, to which it had been referred, and particularly that the report should be made by me— But he did not say the desire of whom— I returned the visit of Mr Martini— His servant told me that he was with Mr Van Buren, and I left a Card— I then returned the visit of Mr Abbott Lawrence at Gadsby’s, and found Mr Granger with him; but they were carrying his dinner in just as I entered his chamber— They were conversing upon the calamitous fire at New-York last Wednesday night, in which nearly seven hundred houses were burnt down and from fifteen to twenty Millions of dollars of property was destroyed— Dr Huntt who came this morning to visit Fanny had first mentioned it to me— Mr Lawrence, and Mr Granger spoke also of the debate yesterday in the House upon the petition to abolish Slavery in the District of Columbia, and both urged me to address the House on the subject— I fear I must— We finished reading the Essay signed M. on the Congress of Nations—

Dark, gloomy foggy day— Morning at the Presbyterian Church, heard Mr Gurley from 2. Corinthians 6.2 “Behold now is the accepted time; behold, now is the day of salvation.” In the afternoon I attended at St John’s Church— Mr Hawley read the Evening service, for the fourth Sunday in Advent, and gave a short discourse from John 4.34. [“]Jesus saith unto them my meat is to do the will of him that sent me, and to finish his work.”— There were very few persons at Church, and it was dark before the Congregation were dismissed— In the evening I began to read the Dissertation marked N. upon the Congress of Nations; the last of the fourteen transmitted to me by Mr Dewey— I finished a Letter to my Son Charles, but otherwise accomplished less of writing than I ought to have done— My Morning reading now is about 20 pages of Mosheim’s Ecclesiastical History, in Dr Archibald M’Laine’s translation— The work is divided chronologically into Centuries— Then into external and internal history of the Church— The external history into prosperous and calamitous events— The internal history into chapters upon the State of Letters and Philosophy during the century, the Doctors and Ministers and form of Government of the Church. The Doctrines—the Rites and Ceremonies; and the divisions and Heresies which successively arose— This partition is repeated from century to century— There is a more general division of the whole subject into four Books— 1 from the Birth of Christ to the time of Constantine— 2. Thence to the age of Charlemagne 3. Thence to the reformation of Luther and 4. thence to the time, and thence to the publication of the Book in 1755— Dr M’Laine’s preface is dated Decr. 1764— Mosheim was a Lutheran, and his History is not partial to the Church of Rome— Neither is it bigoted against that Church— He is rather too credulous in the admission of miracles after the age of the Apostles. His translator is more philosophical—

I lost my repose last Night, and therefore rose the later this morning— I found the House in Session, and Cambreleng from the Committee of Ways and Means presenting a Bill for the relief of the sufferers by the late Conflagration at New-York— Whittlesey however first obtained leave to present sundry Bills from the Committee of Claims; which were received, twice read, ordered to be printed with the Reports and referred to a Committee of the whole, and made the order of the day to-morrow— Grennell next introduced several other Bills from the same Committee; after which Cambreleng’s Bill was received, ordered to be printed, and referred to the Committee of the whole on the state of the Union— Then the unfinished business of Friday was taken up.— Waddy Thompson of no— Joab Lawler of Alabama, offered a Resolution that Congress had not the Constitutional right to abolish Slavery in the District of Columbia, and another that the House would receive no petition, praying therefor— Wise offered the same Resolutions otherwise expressed—moved a suspension of the Rules, that he might move to lay on the table Hammond’s motion to reject the Petition, and offer his Resolutions— He called for the yeas and nays which were 115 to 101 against suspending the rules— Then came the motion to reconsider the reference of a petition from Cummington presented by Briggs, to the Committee on the District of Columbia—against which I addressed the house and was answered by Bouldin, and byAn adjournment was then moved, but suspended for a Message from the President with Documents relating to a bequest from an Englishman named Simonson for the establishment of a learned Institution in the City of Washington— The Message was at my motion referred to a Committee of Nine— Vanderpoel came to my Seat, and said he thought it ought to be referred to the Committee on the District of Columbia— Adjourned soon after 3.— After dinner Mr Reily, brought me a Memorial of his Mother to Congress, which at his request I promised to present— Mr John Connell was here this Evening.

Attended the Committee for the revisal of the Rules of the House. Abijah Mann jr. Francis Thomas, Lewis Williams, C. C. Cambreleng, Horace Everett, Gorham Parks, James Parker, and George Chambers, with myself were the members; all present— Mr Cambreleng however only for a few minutes— Various amendments and additions to the rules were proposed and discussed; and one to two adopted— The Committee adjourned to meet again at ten O’Clock to-morrow— In the House Lane of Indiana came to my Seat, and claimed the Smithson, bequest Message as appurtenant to the Committee on the District of Columbia— I told him I did not know whether it did or not, but that I should call the Select Committee together, and if they should find it appertaining peculiarly to the District, they would ask to be discharged, and that it should be referred to that Committee.— Upon the reading of the Journal the Select Committee were announced, and I am the Chairman— The Speaker then said the unfinished business of yesterday was the reconsideration of the reference of the Petition from Cummington for the abolition of Slavery in the District of Columbia to the Committee on the District— The debate was then continued by Speeches, from Wise of Virginia, Dromgoole of Virginia, Granger, Mann, and Beardsley of New-York, and Ingersoll of Pennsylvania— After 3. O’Clock Slade of Vermont moved an adjournment, announcing his intention to speak upon the subject to-morrow.— Granger’s Speech was short but spirited and pungent— Wise and Dromgoole made frequent and direct allusion to what I said yesterday— Wise maintained that Congress had no right to abolish Slavery in the District of Columbia, and quoted the provision that private property shall not be taken for public uses without compensation—and he complained that runaway Slaves should not be recovered in the North Notwithstanding the Constitutional provision, that they should be restored— Joseph R. Ingersoll proposed a Resolution declaring in the broadest terms that the Constitution of the United States recognizes the right of the People of the Southern States to hold Slaves— A strange concession for a Pennsylvanian

I attended at ten O’Clock the Committee on the Rules—present Mann the Chairman, Williams, Everett, Thomas, Parker and Chambers—absent Cambreleng and Parks— Sundry Amendments to the Rules were proposed, and discussed—some adopted and some rejected—the Chairman was finally directed to Report to the House—my rule respecting censure for words spoken in debate, was to my surprise unanimously agreed to— My proposed addition to the rule that Petitions shall not be debated on the day when presented was much discussed and at last reluctantly agreed to— Only two or three others were adopted— Those proposed by Thomas for requiring a bond with sureties from the Serjeant at Arms, and for admitting District Attornies upon the floor behind the bar; and that of Parker for requiring the members to sit uncovered— In the House immediately after the reading of the Journal I addressed the Speaker; who said the floor belonged to Slade— With his consent I stated that the Select Committee on the Ohio-Boundary had been ordered within one day of a fortnight since— That notice had then been given of an intention to move a reconsideration of the vote and of transferring the subject to another Committee— That on the Monday following, ten days ago, the appointment of the Committees had been announced, and the motion for reconsideration had been made— That I had waited until this time without applying to the Clerk for the Papers, in expectation that the House would decide the question of reconsideration; but I should not feel justified in waiting longer; and gave notice that I should this day notify the members of the Select Committee to meet to-morrow Morning.— Slade then made his Speech, of about an hour and a half, and was followed by James Garland of Virginia on the Slavery side of the question; after which, Mann of New-York moved the previous question— He had already spoken, and Parks of Maine claimed therefore the floor before him; but he said it was to move the Previous question— The Speaker decided that he was entitled to the floor, the rule not applying to the case—the Previous Question was seconded; carried—the reference of the Petition was reconsidered, and it was laid on the table—and the House adjourned. I desired the Speaker to have his decision explicitly noted on the Journal, not being satisfied with it as correct— I notified the Committee on the Michigan Boundary Message to meet to morrow Morning— Mr Frye was here this Evening.

Met at half past ten this morning at the Chamber of the Committee of Manufactures, the Select Committee on the Michigan Boundary Message.— All the members present, consisting of Benjamin Hardin; John M. Patton, James I. M’Kay, Philemon Dickerson, Charles E Haynes, William J. Grayson, Franklin Pierce, and Andrew T. Judson— The Committee had only one printed sheet of the Message and Documents before them—the rest, probably five or six Sheets being yet at the Printers— A Letter addressed to me as Chairman of the Committee was received, signed by twelve members of the Ohio Delegation, requesting the Committee not to proceed upon the business until the House should have decided upon the motion for reconsideration of the reference to this Committee.— Accordingly, the Committee unanimously determined to adjourn until the House shall decide the question of reconsideration; and if the decision should be to leave the reference with the Committee, the Chairman should again call the Committee together— At the House, Mr Thomson of Ohio moved that the House should this day at one O’Clock proceed to the choice of a Chaplain, which was agreed to— Then came the question of the reference of the Michigan Institution Message to a Select Committee; or to the Committee on the Territories— Vinton of Ohio moved that it should be referred to the Committee on the Judiciary of which Beardsley is chairman— Storer of Ohio, Lane of Indiana, and Reynolds of Illinois were all for the reference to the Committee on the Judiciary— Mason of Virginia feebly supported his motion for reference to a Select Committee— Howard more earnestly pleaded for the Committee on the Territories, and the hour of one came, and the ballots for chaplain commenced— Five or six persons were nominated; among whom was Oliver C. Comstock, of New-York, heretofore a member of the House, and now nominated by Richard M. Johnson, to whom it was said he had given a certificate of character— There were five ballots and at last Stockton was chosen— The House then adjourned over to Monday. I spoke to Overton Carr, the Door keeper of the House, about the seventeen boys employed by him, without any authority whatever— There is among them a Son of Stephen B. Leonard one of the members of the House from New-York.

Mr Samuel Moore, heretofore director of the Mint of the United States at Philadelphia called on me this morning— He spoke to me yesterday at the House, and is now engaged in a gold mining Company; which has imported certain machinery from England, for working the mine, in Virginia— They have a memorial to be presented to the House by Mr Joseph R. Ingersoll for a remission of duties, for which Mr Moore bespoke my aid or forbearance— He supposed that as chairman of the Committee of Manufactures I might think myself obliged to oppose it— I promised him that I would confer with the other members of the Committee, and if they should not incline to oppose the Memorial, I should not myself be so disposed— Mr Moore spoke also of the state of our relations with France— Morning visit from Mr G. Chambers, a member of the House from Pennsylvania, and had some conversation with him concerning the multitude of boys employed by the door-keeper of the House— I paid several visits—to President Duer of Columbia College and Mr Abbott Lawrence at Gadsby’s, but neither of them was at home— To Mr Lay and Mr Love whom I found, and where I met Mr Southard; and to Harmar Denny, and to Messrs. Pearce, Sprague and Borden, all of whom I saw— Mr Denny had just returned from Harrisburg where he has been attending an Anti-masonic State Convention, preparatory to the next Presidential Election— Denny was President of the Convention, but they nominated W. H. Harrison, as their Candidate, much against his inclination which was in favour of Daniel Webster. With my wife and Mary we dined at Mr Frye’s—Mr and Mrs W. S. Smith—Mr and Mrs S. B. Barrell—Captain Page of the army, and Walter Hellen were there— We also spent the Evening there, and played at Whist— There was a Ball last Evening at the President’s House— The first given by General Jackson since he has been there. It was a substitute for the Drawing Rooms, which had become so promiscuous, so crowded, and so disorderly that he has been obliged to discontinue them—

I answered a Letter from B. F. Hallett, and wrote two other short ones— Received sundry visits from members of Congress by Cards—and returned the visits of Leonard Jarvis and H. Clay. Jarvis was out, and Mr Clay gone to Baltimore— He is in deep affliction for the loss of the only daughter he had left; and who died very suddenly since he came from home.— I visited also G. M. Briggs and Philo C. Fuller at Fletcher’s and found with them Mr Hazeltine of New-York— In the Evening I read part of the Dissertation N on the Congress of Nations, but could not finish it— I have also received on this and several preceding days, Letters, relating to business, public and private, pending or soon to be brought before Congress. Among them one from Francis Page a Virginian, son of Governor Page, and son in Law of the late General Thomas Nelson—requesting my support to a petition from his heirs, for remuneration for losses sustained by him in the revolutionary War— One from John F. Lewis of Philadelphia; asking my aid for the passage of a Bill for his relief by the remission of duties upon matting.— One from J. W. Allen, of Manchester, Massachusetts, soliciting my support and influence for a memorial, from the Inhabitants of that Town, Essex and Salem, for an Appropriation, of 5000 dollars to remove a ledge of rocks at the Mouth of the river— One from James Callan, a civil Engineer with the map of a survey of the disputed Ohio and Michigan Boundary— One from Henry Fry with a printed Memorial to Congress and Documents—one from Joseph Morton of Milton, with two copies of a printed Document of the Senate at the last Session of Congress, upon a claim of the New-England Mississippi Land Company—together with one from Nathaniel Amory at Newport, and a Letter of introduction from P. P. F. Degrand recommending Major Joseph Grafton who comes as an Agent for claims under the Bastrop title— Papers of this kind are accumulating upon me so that to avoid inextricable Confusion with them I must assort them and attend to them in methodical order— The pressure upon my mind from public business is so great that I find it impossible to give to private concerns that attention which is due to them—yet they must not be neglected—

My grand-child Mary-Louisa, was taken extremely ill in the Night, and continued in great suffering the whole of this day— Dr Huntt was twice sent for to attend her; and came and prescribed for her, without obtaining relief— At the Presbyterian Church this morning a young man recently from the theological institution at Princeton, New-Jersey, but a native of New-Haven, Connecticut, named Bishop, preached from 2. Corinthians 4.18.—“the things which are seen are temporal.” a discourse of great power and eloquence— Full of thought and of feeling; generally well-expressed— His delivery too was very impressive, and his reading intelligent and with well placed accent; emphasis, pause and inflection— In dwelling upon the instability of all human concerns, opinions, desires, joys, sorrows, and fortunes his topics were selected with judgment and treated with delicacy, and in some passages with deep pathos— There were transient allusions to the day, the closing Sabbath of the year, and to the melancholy incidents which have clothed the Senate and the Hall with mourning; and he touched on a mothers agonies at the loss of a child in a manner which suffused other eyes, and mine with tears— I went again to hear him in the afternoon when his text was Matthew 7.24. “Therefore, whosoever heareth these sayings of mine, and doeth them, I will liken him, unto a wise man, which built his house upon a rock: 25. And the rain descended, and the floods came, and the winds blew, and beat upon that house; and it fell not; for it was founded upon a rock. 26. And every one that heareth these sayings of mine, and doeth them not, shall be likened unto a foolish man, which built his house upon the sand: 27. And the rain descended, and the floods came, and the winds blew, and beat upon that house: and it fell: and great was the fall of it—” Practical Christianity—good works— Not the favourite presbyterian theme, but mine— Not so deeply affecting as the discourse of the morning; but coin from the same mint, and of the same metal— I pronounce him an admirable preacher— His thoughts have made a lodgement in my Memory, and his doctrine distilled like the dew— Mr John Connell was here this Evening— I wrote Letters and Journal, but with a load of anxiety upon my heart, which can only implore mercy where it dreads judgment— Yet let me hope—

I finished reading the first, and began the second Volume of Mosheim’s Ecclesiastical History— Mr John H. Blake of Boston brought me Letters of Recommendation from Professor J. W. Webster and from John D. and Moses Williams— He is a chemist and is going to Peru and Chili, upon pursuits of chemical Science— I went with him to the Department of State, and, the Secretary Mr Forsyth, not being there, introduced him to Asbury Dickins, the Chief Clerk— Mr Blake wishes for some protecting authority from the Government; but will probably obtain only a Passport— I asked him to call on me again to-morrow, morning, and promised to give him a Letter to Mr Forsyth— Major Joseph Grafton was also here; an agent for claimants under the Bastrop colour of title— At the House, a Select Committee of seven upon the Public Buildings was ordered at the Motion of Leonard Jarvis, and the Joint Committee on the part of the House, on the Library— The day was consumed in disposing of the two Messages of the President, relating to Michigan— There was some further debate on the reference of the Message with the Constitution— John Y. Mason withdrew his motion for the reference to a select Committee, and Howard, who had moved for the Committee on the Territories, consented that the question should first be taken upon the Committee on the Judiciary—and it was carried— Then came the question of reconsideration of the reference of the Boundary Message to a Select Committee, which was debated about two hours, and in which I alone spoke against the Reconsideration, and Storer,and Vinton of Ohio, Lane of Indiana and Reynolds of Illinois in favour of it— The reconsideration was carried by yeas and nays 107 to 79—28 majority, and there are 29 votes of the States, interested against the right of Michigan— I then withdrew my motion for the reference to a Select Committee and the Message was referred to the Committee on the Judiciary, of which Beardsley is Chairman— Mason came to my Seat and remarked that the opposition members almost all voted for the reference to the Judiciary Committee, and it was so. And they with the 29 interested members carried the vote— I walked home with Leonard Jarvis. My grand-child Mary Louisa, appears to be better.

I rose early this morning, and was employed in writing till breakfast time— Mr Blake came and I gave him a recommendatory Letter to the Secretary of State— At the House Cambreleng, Chairman of the Committee of Ways and Means, moved to suspend the rules to enable him to report several of the Appropriation Bills: the vote was 97 to 50: not quite two thirds— The presentation of Petitions was then taken up— I presented the Memorial of Barbara Reily, Widow of William Reily, which was referred to the Committee on Revolutionary Pensions— I asked leave to offer a Resolution connected with the Petition; but objection was made, and my Resolution was not received— All the States were called for the reception of Petitions; and a great multitude of them were presented and referred— The Reports from standing Committees were then called for, and Cambreleng, reported the appropriation Bills for fortifications, for the army, the Navy, the Revolutionary Pensions, and a Bill of Appropriations in part for the support of Government—they were twice read by their titles ordered to be printed and referred to the Committee of the Whole on the State of the Union— The early report of these Bills, is the first fruit of the New Rule, introduced at my instance—would that the other consequences intended by me might follow with equal and more efficacy— Many other Bills were reported by the Chairmen of the other standing Committees and were duly referred to the Committee of the whole, and made the order of the day to-morrow. Bell of Tennessee rose and said that the part of the President’s Message, relating to an Amendment of the Constitution of the United States, in the election of President and Vice-President, had been some time since referred to a Select Committee, and he wished to enquire when the Report of the Committee might be expected— A member answered that there had as yet been no meeting of the Committee— Adjourned near 4 O’Clock— On reaching home I found my wife very ill; in bed— Mrs Frye and Mrs W. S. Smith were here— My wife was seized very suddenly this morning, shortly after I went out.— Walter Hellen was here after dinner. Mr Taliaferro and Mr Reed in the Evening; and Mr John Connell, with the Petition and papers of the Heirs of Robert Fulton.—

My wife was confined all this day to her bed— Her Sisters and her brother were here in the course of the morning— Mr Frye and Mr Smith were also here, and the latter brought a man with a pair of Coach horses for sale; being those of Mr Pageot the Chargé d’Affaires of France who is on the point of departure— After some inspection of the Horses, by myself, and by the Coachman Wilson I purchased them, for 260 dollars, with a check for which I sent Wilson to Mr Pageot, whose receipt he brought back.— This traffick detained me till so late that when I reached the Capitol, the House was in Session, and Mr Beardsley was calling up his Resolution for the admission of Isaac E Crary the Representative elect from Michigan, upon the floor of the House. objection was made, and Beardsley moved the suspension of the Rules and called for the yeas and nays— It was carried by a vote oftoand the Resolution as modified by Beardsley, to admit Mr Crary as a Spectator was carried without opposition— Mr Chambers of Pennsylvania then asked leave of the House to present a Petition and have it referred—no objection was made and the petition was admitted—upon which I immediately asked the same indulgence of the House, and it was not denied— I presented the memorial of the Heirs of Robert Fulton and accompanying papers which had been put into my hands by Mr Connell; and they were referred to the Committee of Claims— Mr Connell had laid on my table nine printed copies of the documents of the case for the use of the members of the Committee of Claims, which I gave to Mr Whittlesey— An effort was made to call the States over for Petitions but it failed.— W. B. Shepard chairman of the Committee on the District of Columbia, had moved the reference of a Memorial for the recharter of one of the District Banks, to that Committee; and Thomas of Maryland had moved as an Amendment its reference to a Select Committee with an Instruction for an investigation, and other extraordinary powers— After a debate of three hours, the Question was taken on reference to the district Committee and lost 88 to 113. I moved to strike out the Power of the Committee to confer with a Committee of the Senate— Thomas accepted the Amendment— Adjourned at 4— Snow.

I had yesterday notified the members of the Select Committee on the President’s Message, relating to the Smithsonian bequest, to meet at the chamber of the Committee of Manufactures, at eleven O’Clock this morning— I rode up to the Capitol, and attended the Meeting accordingly— The members present wereGarland, of Virginia, T. M. T. M’Kennan, D. J. Pearce, Rice Garland of Louisiana,Chapin of New-York and Edward H. Hannegan of Indiana, Those absent were Jesse Speight of North-Carolina, who is sick, and Francis Thomas of Maryland— The Message and Documents as printed were read by me— Three Members of the Committee, Garland of Virginia, Hannegan of Indiana and Chapin of New-York expressed doubts whether the bequest ought to be accepted— Garland moved an adjournment of the Meeting to this day fortnight—but it was agreed to adjourn to next Saturday week. I proposed to report a request that this Committee should be discharged and that the subject should be referred to a joint Committee of the two Houses.— In the House, the two Members from the State of Mississippi Claiborne and Dickson appeared, were sworn and took their Seats— Wardwell moved a suspension of the Rules to consider a Resolution for discontinuing the practice of having public worship in the Hall on Sundays, but the House refused. Thomas’s motion for a select Committee with Instructions for a select Committee on the applications for the recharter of Banks in the District of Columbia was resumed— M’Kennon offered an Amendment to call for the Correspondence of Members of Congress with Deposit Banks, and Kinnard of Indiana an amendment on that, to call for the correspondence of Members of Congress with the Bank of the United States. I spoke against both the Amendments and against the Instructions and especially against a slanderous imputation by Beardsley upon the President and Directors of the Bank of the United States— Galbraith moved the previous Question which was carried 87 to 83. the main question was then carried by yeas and nays 100 to 96. The question of reference was then carried without opposition—and the Instructions were divided—the examination and scrutiny were carried; but the reference of all future Memorials was abandoned by Thomas himself and rejected— The House adjourned over to Monday— Close of the year with blessing to Almighty God for the past, and humble supplication for the future.
